sn9.13:1.1: At one time several mendicants were staying in the Kosalan lands in a certain forest grove. They were restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
sn9.13:1.2: The deity haunting that forest had sympathy for those mendicants, and wanted what’s best for them. So they approached those mendicants wanting to stir them up, and addressed them in verse:
sn9.13:2.5: Knowing that the world was impermanent
sn9.13:2.6: they made an end of suffering.
sn9.13:3.1: But now they’ve made themselves hard to look after,
sn9.13:3.3: They eat and eat and then lie down,
sn9.13:3.4: unconscious in the homes of others.
sn9.13:4.1: Having raised my joined palms to the Saṅgha,
sn9.13:4.2: I speak here only about certain people.
sn9.13:4.4: just like those who have passed away.
sn9.13:6.1: Impelled by that deity, those mendicants were struck with a sense of urgency.
